results.headline: That Guest? He Might Be a Lady Killer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lodger

results.summary_short: “The Lodger” is a spooky story ruined by lumpen dialogue, cloddish performances and a director and writer (David Ondaatje) oblivious to both.

results.headline: Novel’s Characters Leap From the Page, Literally

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inkheart

results.summary_short: “Inkheart,” a muddled film adaptation of a children’s best seller by Cornelia Funke, celebrates the magic of books, but it can also be taken as a cautionary tale.

results.headline: Looking for the Origins of the Gangs of Los Angeles
results.display_title: Crips and Bloods: Made in America

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crips and Bloods: Made in America

results.summary_short: With “Crips and Bloods: Made in America,” the director Stacy Peralta manages to put a human face on a subject that tends to inspire inflamed debate.

results.headline: Looking Back, With Affection and Angst

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Of Time and the City

results.summary_short: The documentary “Of Time and the City” looks at the pains and pleasures of growing up Roman Catholic and gay in postwar Britain.

results.headline: Pictures More Influential Than Words

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Photograph

results.summary_short: In “The Photograph,” an unlikely friendship eases an old man’s death and a young woman’s life.

results.headline: Where Guns Fall From the Sky
results.display_title: Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms

results.summary_short: “Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms” is a depressing, scattershot survey of the spread of weaponry around the world, especially in Africa.

results.headline: Watch Out for That Pickax; It’s Hurtling From the Screen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Bloody Valentine

results.summary_short: A strange synergy of old and new, “My Bloody Valentine 3D” blends cutting-edge technology and old-school prosthetics to produce something both familiar and alien: gore you can believe in.

results.headline: Sometimes Groucho’s Cigar Is Not Just a Cigar

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pervert's Guide to Cinema

results.summary_short: In “The Pervert’s Guide to Cinema,” the Slovenian philosopher Slavoj Zizek subjects more than 40 mostly classic films to psychoanalytic scrutiny.

results.headline: Inside Dancing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ballerina

results.summary_short: “Ballerina” parts the curtain on a rarefied realm where the bodies of young girls are stretched, twisted and sent floating on air.

results.headline: An Elderly Loner Seeks Distraction

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sublet

results.summary_short: Bad as it is, nothing in “The Sublet” warrants derision — nor, to be frank, your time.

results.headline: A Hapless Security Guard Runs Amok

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paul Blart: Mall Cop

results.summary_short: Fat people are funny. Fat people who fall over are funnier. Fat people who fall over and have humiliating working-class jobs? Stop, you’re killing me!

results.headline: A Rapper’s Tale, Larger Than Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Notorious

results.summary_short: Anyone looking for a dispassionate, evenhanded account of the life of Biggie Smalls will be disappointed, perhaps even dismayed, by “Notorious.”

results.headline: A Tale of Love and Liberation (Puppy and Otherwise)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hotel for Dogs

results.summary_short: “Hotel for Dogs” is a cuter-than-cute, sweeter-than-sweet family film about animal-loving kids who embark on a crusade to rescue all the stray pooches in a fictional city.

results.headline: Insights Arrive at the End of a Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cherry Blossoms: Hanami

results.summary_short: Doris Dörrie’s “Cherry Blossoms” is both a tender tale of cultural crossings and a double portrait of grief.

results.headline: A Kung Fu Extravaganza

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chandni Chowk to China

results.summary_short: “Chandni Chowk to China” seamlessly adds kung fu to the usual blend of comedy, dance and melodrama.

results.headline: In Mozambique, a Road to Self-Discovery
results.display_title: Testament: The Bible in Animation - Jonah

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Testament: The Bible in Animation - Jonah

results.summary_short: With “Sleepwalking Land,” the filmmaker Teresa Prata creates an affecting portrait of life during wartime.

results.headline: Star Log: Trippy Sci-Fi Mash-Up Alert!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mock Up on Mu

results.summary_short: By turns absorbing, confounding, exhausting and altogether stranger than most fiction, “Mock Up on Mu” comes close to defying categorization.

results.headline: Playing at Life With Dad’s Loaded Dice, at Home and in Las Vegas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yonkers Joe

results.summary_short: “Yonkers Joe” tells the story of a card sharp with guilt pangs and his 20-year-old son with Down syndrome.

results.headline: Mengele, the Holocaust and Horror Movie Staples

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unborn

results.summary_short: In “The Unborn,” a young woman attracts creepy bugs and a demonic spirit.

results.headline: Something Forgotten in an Eerie Denmark

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just Another Love Story

results.summary_short: “Just Another Love Story” administers a stinging slap in the face to the popular notion of Denmark as one of the happiest places on earth.
